sections.title: Calm, thorough gum care to steady teeth and implants
sections.body: Gum care focuses on reducing inflammation and protecting the bone and tissues that support your teeth. Gum disease often progresses quietly, with bleeding, bad breath or tenderness as early signs. We assess gum pocket depths, bleeding points and contributing factors such as smoking, medical conditions and bite stress, then recommend care based on your risk level. Treatment may include targeted cleaning below the gum line and guidance on brushing and interdental cleaning that’s realistic to maintain at home. The aim is to stabilise the condition, keep gums comfortable and reduce the chance of long-term problems such as mobility or tooth loss.
bullets: Full periodontal assessments with gentle charting and imaging
Non-surgical therapy focused on deep cleaning and root surface debridement
Personalised maintenance to keep gums, teeth, and implants stable

sections.title: Stable gums protect your bite and overall health
items: Healthy gums keep teeth and implants anchored and comfortable
Preventing inflammation supports fresher breath and everyday comfort
Evidence links uncontrolled gum disease with diabetes control and cardiovascular health
Care plans are judgement-free and paced to suit you

sections.title: Gingivitis vs periodontitis
sections.body: Gingivitis is surface-level inflammation that can usually be reversed with tailored cleaning and home care. Periodontitis affects the deeper support around teeth or implants, leading to pocketing and bone loss. Early, steady treatment limits damage and keeps treatment conservative.
bullets: We check for bleeding, plaque build-up, and gum measurements
X-rays or scans help us see bone levels where needed
You’ll receive a clear, written plan before any therapy

sections.title: What patients often notice
items: Bleeding gums, soreness, or bad breath that keeps returning
Gum recession, spacing changes, or teeth feeling slightly mobile
History of smoking, stress, diabetes, or family tendency to gum disease
Peri-implant inflammation such as redness or bleeding around implants

sections.title: Non-surgical care first, with clear reviews
items: Comprehensive assessment with periodontal charting and tailored photos/scans
Personalised home care coaching, including interdental cleaning and toothpaste advice
Root surface debridement (deep cleaning) with topical anaesthetic or local anaesthetic for comfort
Airflow-style stain removal or polishing where suitable after plaque and tartar are removed
Re-evaluation of pocket depths and gum response after healing
Supportive maintenance visits to keep disease stable; onward referral discussed for complex cases
sections.strapline: Most patients stabilise with non-surgical care and regular maintenance when we work together on habits and reviews.

sections.title: Modern hygiene tools with a gentle touch
sections.body: Ultrasonic scalers, fine hand instruments, and airflow-style finishing help remove plaque and calculus thoroughly. We use numbing gels or local anaesthetic when needed and share measured progress so you feel in control.

sections.title: Keeping gums healthy after treatment
items: Short-term tenderness or temperature sensitivity is common and settles with good home care
Smoking, unmanaged stress, or poorly controlled diabetes can slow healing — we’ll factor this into your plan
Regular supportive periodontal therapy to maintain pocket depth reductions
Clear instructions on cleaning around teeth and implants to protect results

sections.title: Answers to common gum care questions

faqs.question: Does deep cleaning hurt?
faqs.answer: Treatment is planned gently with numbing gels or local anaesthetic where needed. You’ll be guided on what to expect and how to keep things comfortable afterwards.

faqs.question: How long does it take to see improvement?
faqs.answer: Gums often look and feel healthier within weeks, but long-term stability depends on regular maintenance and the risk factors we identify together.

faqs.question: Can gum tissue grow back?
faqs.answer: Inflammation can reduce and pockets can tighten with good care. Recession usually needs protective maintenance rather than regrowth, and we’ll discuss options if grafting or referral is appropriate.

faqs.question: What about implants with gum inflammation?
faqs.answer: Peri-implant tissues can often be stabilised with careful cleaning, airflow-style stain removal, and close reviews. If advanced peri-implantitis is present, we’ll outline referral options calmly.
